Most Treasures in Munchkin are Items, and Items have a Gold Piece value. A "No Value" card is equivalent to zero Gold Pieces and is considered an Item.

All Items you have in play are considered "carried." Items that are actually giving you a bonus are "equipped." To indicate un-equipped Items, turn the cards sideways. You cannot alter the status of your Items during a combat or while running away.

Anyone can carry any Item (except for extra Big items; see below), but you may equip only one Headgear, one suit of Armor, one pair of Footgear, and two "I Hand" Items (or one "2 Hands" Item) . . . unless you have a card that lets you ignore these limits, such as Hireling or Cheat!, or unless one of the cards says otherwise. If you are carrying two Headgear cards, for instance, you can equip only one of them at a time.

Some Items have restrictions, such as the Mace of Sharpness, which can only be wielded by a Cleric. Its bonus only counts for someone who is, at the moment, a Cleric.

You cannot discard Item cards "just because." You may sell Items for a level, trade Items with other players, or give an Item to another player who wants it (see below). You may discard Items to power certain Class and Race abilities. And a Curse or a monster's Bad Stuff (see p. 5) may force you to get rid of something!

**Big Items:** You may carry any number of Small items, but only one Big one. (Any item not marked Big is considered Small.) You may not discard one Big item to play another; you must sell the first Item, trade it, lose it to a Curse or Bad Stuff, or discard it to power a Class or Race ability.

**ONE-SHOT TREASURES**

A Treasure card with the notation "Usable once only" is commonly referred to as a "one-shot" Treasure. These are typically used during combat to enhance the munchkins or monsters, and can be played from your hand or from the table. While some have other effects, it is crucial to read the card carefully. Discard these cards once the combat is over or their effect is resolved.

Importantly, one-shot Items with a Gold Piece value can be sold for levels, just like other Items.

**OTHER TREASURES**

Other Treasure cards, such as Go Up a Level cards, are not considered Items. Most of these cards specify when they can be played and whether they remain in play or are discarded. A few examples:

- Go Up a Level cards can be played on yourself or any other player at any time, even during combat. Discard them once they are played. Note: You cannot play a Go Up a Level card to give a player the winning level!
- Hireling can be played at any time, on any turn. However, you cannot give a Hireling an Item to carry while you are in combat.

# Items and Trading

If you have more than one item, you must sell them or give them to the lowest-level player(s) who can carry them. If any large items are left over, discard them.

## Trading Items

You can trade items with other players, but not other cards. You can only trade items that are on the table, not the ones in your hand. You can trade at any time, except when you or your trading partner are in combat. In fact, the best time to trade is when it's not your turn.

Any item you receive in a trade must remain in play. You can also give items away without a trade, as a bribe to other players.

## Selling Items for Levels

During your turn, except during combat or Running Away, you can discard items worth a total of at least 1,000 Gold Pieces and immediately go up one level. ("No Value" cards are the same as zero Gold Pieces.) If you discard, for example, 1,100 Gold Pieces worth, you don't get change. But if you can manage 2,000 worth, you can go up two levels at once, and so on.

You can sell items from your hand as well as those you are carrying. However, you cannot sell items to reach Level 10.

**MONSTERS**

During the Kick Open The Door phase, if a monster card is drawn face-up, it immediately attacks the person who drew it. If a monster card is obtained through any other means, it goes into the player's hand and can be played during their own turn to Look For Trouble or played to join another player's fight with the Wandering Monster card.

Each monster card represents a single monster, even if the name on the card is plural.

**MONSTER ENHANCERS**

Certain cards, called monster enhancers, can either raise or lower the combat strength of individual monsters. These also affect the number of Treasures the monsters are worth. Monster enhancers can be played by any player during any combat.

All enhancers on a single monster add together. If there are multiple monsters in a combat, the player who plays each enhancer must choose which monster it applies to.

Exception: Anything that enhances a monster also enhances its Mate. If Ancient, Enraged, and Mate are played on a single monster in any order, you are facing an Ancient Enraged monster and its Ancient Enraged Mate.

**FIGHTING MULTIPLE MONSTERS**

Some cards, such as Wandering Monster, allow your rivals to send other monsters to join the fight. You must defeat their combined combat strengths. Any special abilities, such as forcing you to fight with your Level only, apply to the entire fight. If you have the right cards, you can eliminate one monster from the combat and fight the other(s) normally, but you cannot choose to fight one and Run Away from the other(s). If you eliminate one monster, but then run from the other(s), you don't get any levels or Treasure!

Steeds are a valuable asset to a Munchkin, providing bonuses and enhancing their rider's abilities. These trusty companions can be found in the Door deck and follow normal Item rules. However, no player can possess more than one Steed, unless a Cheat! card is used.

Steeds are considered "Big" items, but do not count against the limit of Big items a player can carry. This designation is used to control which Traps and Curses affect them and to prevent Thieves from pocketing them.

There are specific Items that enhance Steeds, and while Steeds cannot use regular Items, they can use Steed-enhancing Items. Item Enhancers, however, do not affect Steed-enhancing Items.

In the case of a Steed providing a bonus or penalty to Run Away, this replaces the rider's bonus. For example, an Elf normally has a bonus to Run Away, but if riding the Turtle Steed, they would have a penalty. If a Steed provides a penalty to Run Away, the player may discard the Steed before rolling to flee, avoiding the penalty but sending the card to the discard pile.

A player who draws a face-up Steed may choose to treat it as a monster instead. In this case, its Level is equal to twice the combat bonus at the top of the card, and defeating it grants one Treasure and one level. Monster Enhancers may be played on Steeds being fought as monsters, and they have their normal effects. If a Steed is attacked as a monster, the consequence is "Lose a level."

# Turn Phases

Your turn begins as soon as the previous player's turn ends. Arrange your cards as desired, then proceed to the following phases:

1. **Kick Open The Door**: Draw one card from the Door deck and turn it face up.
   - If it's a monster, you must fight it. Refer to [Combat](#combat) on page 3.
   - If the card is a curse, apply it to you immediately (if possible) and discard it (unless it has a persistent effect or you keep the card as a reminder of an upcoming effect).
   - If you draw any other card, you may either put it in your hand or play it immediately.
2. **Look For Trouble/Loot The Room**:
   - If you fought a monster during phase 1, skip this phase and go to phase 3.
   - If you did NOT draw a monster when you first opened the door, you have two choices:
     - **Look For Trouble**: Play a monster from your hand and fight it, just as if you had found it when you kicked open the door.
     - **Loot The Room**: Draw a second card from the Door deck, face down, and place it in your hand.
3. **Charity**:
   - If you have more than five cards in your hand, you must play enough cards to get you to five or below.
   - For example, you can play Curses, sell Items from your hand, or play Items to the table.
   - If you cannot reduce your hand to five cards, or do not want to, you must give the excess cards to the player with the lowest Level.
   - If players are tied for lowest, divide the cards as evenly as possible, but it's up to you who gets the bigger set(s) of leftovers.
   - If YOU are the lowest or tied for lowest, just discard the excess.

As soon as you are finished with Charity, the next player's turn begins.

# Faster Play Rules

For a quicker game, add a "Phase 0" called "Listen At The Door". At the beginning of your turn, before performing any other action, draw a face-down Door card, which you may choose to play or not. Proceed with arranging cards and Kick Open The Door as usual. If you Loot The Room, draw a face-down Treasure, not a Door.

A Curse typically affects its victim immediately (if possible) and is then discarded. However, some Curses have a later game penalty or a continuous effect. Keep these cards until you get rid of the Curse or the penalty takes effect. (Note: Cards kept as reminders cannot be discarded to power Class or Race abilities.)

You can allow shared victories, where if a player reaches Level 10 in a fight where you are the helper, you also win the game. If someone plays a "your next combat" Curse on you while you are in combat, it counts in that combat. The same is true for a "your next turn" Curse played during your turn.
